instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
turn on, fan on, no data usb

PPCPUVCCIO_S0_REG_R=1.07
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_REG_R</SIGNAL>=0.90
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL>=0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL>=0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_R</SIGNAL>=0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL>=1.5v
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>=0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
Missing CPU core may have various causes.
BIOS, PCH, CPU and <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> are all involved there.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is good.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> comes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=3.2
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is good also 
at one end <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> has 12.6v and at the other 0.51v is that normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
That's normal.
No voltage at all at <RESISTOR>R7510</RESISTOR>/20 for sure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: SURE THERE IS NO VOLTAGE, DIODE MODE 0.015

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
Any history available?

All the other big coils have voltage?
Compare with good board.

Just in case, try known good BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
the story is that a battery is placed in it, and after a week I return with the problem, all the voltages are in the coils except
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL>=0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL>=0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_R</SIGNAL>=0v

I already tried bios problem persists

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
Just in case, change <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and check all surrounding components and solders.
I suspect PCH, or CPU; be sure all voltages from page 22 are good.

You can also try to heat PCH and CPU using quality flux.
